facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2331 of 1968 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 24, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 24, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 14433 of 1968.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court case was Civil Misc. Writ No. 14433 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: P. Bajpai, S. M. Jain and G. M. Wantoo, for the appellant. P. Rana, for respondents Nos.

facts.text: Appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court at Allahabad for a quo warranto against respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: Shelat, J. I he appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court at Allahabad for a quo warranto against respondent 1, challenging therein his appointment as

facts.text: Writ petition challenged respondent 1's appointment as Judge of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Judge of that High Court. The ground on which he challenged the appointment was that though respondent 1 was enrolled as an advocate more than 20 years ago,

facts.text: Writ petition heard preliminarily by Broome and G. Kumar, JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition came up for a preliminary hearing before Broome and G. Kumar, JJ., when it was urged that the expression an advocate of a High Court

facts.text: Broome, J. held that 'an advocate of a High Court' means an advocate enrolled as such, irrespective of practice location.

anchor.surface_text: Broome, J. held that on a plain reading of the relevant clauses the companyrect interpretation of the expression an advocate of a High Court meant an advocate enrolled as an advocate of a High Court, irrespective of whether on such enrolment he practised in a High Court or a companyrt or companyrts subordinate to the High Court

facts.text: G. Kumar, J. held that 'an advocate of a High Court' means one who practised in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: G. Kumar, J., on the other hand, accepted the companytention urged on behalf of the appellant and held that the expression an advocate of a High Court meant one who has practised for the required period in a High Court,

facts.text: Difference of opinion between Broome J. and G. Kumar J., matter referred to Mathur, J.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore, a person who has practised only in a companyrt or companyrts subordinate to the High Court would number answer the qualification required under Art. 217 2  b . Such a difference of opinion having thus arisen between the two learned Judges, the matter was referred to Mathur, J.,

facts.text: Mathur, J. agreed with Broome J.

anchor.surface_text: who agreed with Broome J., and thereupon the writ petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Writ petition was dismissed by Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal on certificate granted by the High Court challenges the companyrectness of the order dismissing the writ petition.

facts.text: Appeal filed on certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant repeated before us the same companytentions which were urged first before Broome and Kumar, JJ., and later on before- Matkur, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with Broome J. and Mathur J. on interpretation of Art. 217(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the language used in Art. 217  2   b  is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J.

facts.text: Respondent 1 entitled to appointment as he was enrolled advocate of High Court for over 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: The expression an advocate of a High Court must, therefore, mean, in the light of these provisions, an advocate whose name has been enrolled as an advocate of a High Court, numbermatter whether he practised in the High Court itself or in companyrts subordinate to it or both.

facts.text: Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 defined legal practitioner including Advocate of any High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 defined by S. 3 a legal practitioner as meaning an Advocate, Vakil or Attorney of any High Court, a Pleader, Mukhtar or Revenue- agent.

facts.text: Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926 defined advocate as one entered in roll of advocates of a High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Bar Councils Act, XXXVIIII of 1926 also defined an advocate meaning one entered in the roll of advocates of a High Court under the provisions of this Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended that Art. 233(2) uses 'an advocate' differently from 'advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellant's first contention.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the language used in Art. 217  2   b  is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J. One broad point against the interpretation sought by companynsel for the appellant would be that the expression an advocate of a High Court in its ordinary plain meaning must mean a person who has by enrolling himself under the relevant provisions of law become an advocate of a High Court.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'an advocate of a High Court' in Article 217(2)(b) of the Constitution requires practice for at least ten years in the High Court itself, or suffices enrolment as an advocate of the High Court irrespective of the place of practice?

anchor.surface_text: Art. 217 2  b  of the Constitution, as admittedly respondent 1 was all along practising at Benaras and number in the High Court. The writ petition came up for a preliminary hearing before Broome and G. Kumar, JJ., when it was urged that the expression an advocate of a High Court in Art. 217 2  b  meant an advocate practising in the High Court and number one practising in a companyrt or companyrts subordinate to-the High Court.

issues.text: Whether the difference in language between 'an advocate' in Article 233(2) and 'an advocate of a High Court' in Articles 217(2)(b) and 124(3), and analogy in Article 124(3)(a)-(b), indicates a requirement of practice in the High Court for eligibility as High Court Judge?

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the language used in Art. 217  2   b  is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J.

arguments.claim: Prior statutes like Legal Practitioners Act 1879 use 'advocate of High Court' to mean enrolled, entitled to practice in HC or subordinates

anchor.surface_text: The Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 defined by S. 3 a legal practitioner as meaning an Advocate, Vakil or Attorney of any High Court, a Pleader, Mukhtar or Revenue- agent.

arguments.claim: Indian Bar Councils Act 1926 defines advocate as entered in roll of High Court advocates, entitled to practice in HC or other courts

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Bar Councils Act, XXXVIIII of 1926 also defined an advocate meaning one entered in the roll of advocates of a High Court under the provisions of this Act.

arguments.claim: GOI Act 1935 s.220(3)(d) used similar phrase for pleader of High Court meaning enrolled

anchor.surface_text: The same phraseology was also repeated in s. 220 3  d  of the Government -of India Act, 1935, except for one change, namely, that in calculating 10 years standing, his standing as a pleader of 2 or more High Courts in succession was also to be included.

arguments.claim: Petitioner's interpretation would create anomaly in Art. 124(3): SC practitioner not eligible

anchor.surface_text: If the meaning of the expression an advocate of a high Court as suggested on behalf of the appellant were to be accepted a very strange anomaly, as pointed out by Broome, J., would result while construing Art. 124 3 , namely, that an advocate who has practised in the Supreme Court for the required period but not in a High Court would not be eligible for the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court.

arguments.claim: Art. 233(2) uses 'an advocate' simpliciter because Constitution did not wish to insist on High Court practice

anchor.surface_text: Counsel next relied on Art. 233  2  in support of the construction suggested by him of Art. 217 2  b  and pointed out that wherever the Constitution did not wish to insist on an appointee having been an advocate practising in a High Court,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is standing of ten years as. a pleader of a High Court. This clearly high- lights the point that what s.220 3  in the 1935 Act required as a qualifica

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction has no significance after Advocates Act 1961 s.16; only two classes of advocates

arguments.claim: Distinction in Art. 233(2) between 'an advocate' and 'advocate of a High Court' in 217 has no significance post Advocates Act 1961

anchor.surface_text: The distinction, if any, between the words an advocate in Art. 233 2  and the words an advocate of a High Court in Art. 217 2  b  has no significance in any event after the coming into force of the Advocate Act, 1961, as by virtue of s. 16 of that Act there are no only two classes of persons entitled to practice, namely, senior advocates and other advocates.

holdings.text: The language used in Art. 217(2)(b) is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than that 'an advocate of a High Court' means an advocate enrolled as such irrespective of whether he practised in the High Court or courts subordinate thereto.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the language used in Art. 217  2   b  is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J. One broad point against the interpretation sought by companynsel for the appellant would be that the expression an advocate of a High Court in its ordinary plain meaning must mean a person who has by enrolling himself under the relevant provisions of law become an advocate of a High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and ordinary meaning of the expression requires enrolment as an advocate of a High Court; confirmed by consistent usage in prior statutes (Legal Practitioners Act 1879, Indian Bar Councils Act 1926, GOI Act 1935); agrees with Broome J. and Mathur J.

holdings.text: The expression 'an advocate of a High Court' must mean an advocate whose name has been enrolled as an advocate of a High Court, no matter whether he practised in the High Court itself or in courts subordinate to it or both.

anchor.surface_text: The expression an advocate of a High Court must, therefore, mean, in the light of these provisions, an advocate whose name has been enrolled as an advocate of a High Court, numbermatter whether he practised in the High Court itself or in companyrts subordinate to it or both.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from definitions and entitlements to practice in prior statutes; enrolment entitles to practice in High Court or subordinates without distinction based on actual practice location.

holdings.text: We are in agreement with Broome and Mathur JJ on the construction placed by them on Art. 217(2)(b); the first contention of counsel for the appellant must fail.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are in agreement with Broome and Mathur, JJ., on the companystruction placed by them on Art. 217  2   b . The first companytention of companynsel for the appellant, therefore, must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's claim requiring High Court practice; plain text and historical statutes support enrolment sufficiency; avoids anomaly in Art. 124(3).

holdings.text: The distinction, if any, between 'an advocate' in Art. 233(2) and 'an advocate of a High Court' in Art. 217(2)(b) has no significance after the coming into force of the Advocates Act, 1961, as s.16 provides only two classes of persons entitled to practise: senior advocates and other advocates.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel next relied on Art. 233  2  in support of the companystruction suggested by him of Art. 217 2  b  and pointed out that wherever the Constitution did number wish to insist on an appointee having been an advocate practising in a High Court,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advocates Act 1961 s.16 eliminates prior distinctions in classes of practitioners; does not support implying High Court practice requirement from linguistic difference.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are in agreement with Broome and Mathur, JJ., on the construction placed by them on Art. 217 2 b . The first contention of counsel for the appellant, therefore, must fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contentions rejected; High Court order dismissing writ petition upheld

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the language used in Art. 217  2   b  is plain and incapable of bearing an interpretation other than the one given by Broome, J., and agreeing with him by Mathur, J. One broad point against the interpretation sought by companynsel for the appellant would be that the expression an advocate of a High Court in its ordinary plain meaning must mean a person who has by enrolling himself under the relevant provisions of law become an advocate of a High Court.
For these reasons we are in agreement with Broome and Mathur, JJ., on the construction placed by them on Art. 217 2 b . The first contention of counsel for the appellant, therefore, must fail.

anchor.surface_text: The expression an advocate of a High Court must, therefore, mean, in the light of these provisions, an advocate whose name has been enrolled as an advocate of a High Court, numbermatter whether he practised in the High Court itself or in companyrts subordinate to it or both.
For these reasons we are in agreement with Broome and Mathur, JJ., on the construction placed by them on Art. 217 2 b . The first contention of counsel for the appellant, therefore, must fail.
